Award.AwardTitle: ECCS-EPCN: Stochastic Power Control and Learning for Energy Grids

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates a computational framework to deal with the stochastic, dynamic, and spatio-temporally distributed nature of forthcoming power systems. The envisioned advances in adaptivity, awareness, and scalability aim at engaging currently inactive electricity consumers in a sustainable power system. Smooth integration of photovoltaics, wind, storage systems, and electric vehicles, will promote innovation and development, in terms of markedly advancing the resource allocation, learning, and monitoring infrastructure.

The proposed research aims for broad socio-technical advances in energy networks. Successful completion of the project will offer cyber innovations to enable systematic integration of stochastic renewable generation while improving end-user satisfaction. Given the universality of the research tools and methodologies, the utility of the proposed research goes well beyond the envisioned application area to the broader fields of optimization, stochastic processes, control systems, machine learning, statistical signal processing, and cyber security. Broader transformative impact will result from pragmatic test cases proposed for validation, involvement of undergraduates in research, and outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The high-level objective of this project is to leverage advances in metering, telecommunication, and power electronics, in order to contribute the desired cyber infrastructure to transform consumer interaction with energy-related engineered systems, and realize the goals of the smart power grid. The completed research contributes to addressing major challenges facing current power networks that include renewable energy sources, demand-response programs, and electric vehicles – all increasing the time-variability, randomness, and modeling complexity of the underlying physical systems. In this context, the project has offered algorithmic innovations in terms of resource allocation, monitoring, and learning tasks that contribute to realizing the vision of advancing knowledge of networked systems, while taking transformative steps toward ensuring adaptability, scalability, and reliability of forthcoming power systems. Intellectual merits and specific outcomes include: power grid topology tracking using online energy-price matrix factorization; ergodic energy management leveraging resource variability in distribution grids; robust workload and energy management for green data centers; scalable electric vehicle charging protocols; voltage regulation for multiphase power distribution grids; two-timescale stochastic dispatch of power distribution networks; topology identification of meshed power grids via nonlinear voltage correlations; randomized block Frank-Wolfe for convergent large-scale network management; robust and scalable power system state estimation (PSSE) via composite optimization and from rank-one measurements; distribution system PSSE using data-driven and physics-guided deep neural networks; power system state forecasting via deep recurrent neural networks; and real-time voltage regulation in distribution grids using deep reinforcement learning.

Together with research, this project had major outcomes also on the educational front. Ten PhDs were supported and the graduates are now faculty members (UC Santa Cruz, VaTech, RPI, Marquette, UC Irvine, Beijing Inst. of Technology), and researchers in the data science Industry (NextEra, Samsung, Google and Amazon).  Monthly reading group meetings were organized on advances related to network science, online convex optimization and machine learning for big data analytics with applications to sensing and resource allocation for communication, social, brain, and power networks with renewables and electric vehicles. Knowledge was disseminated through dozens of tutorials, keynote, plenary and colloquia presentations, journal and conference papers in flagship venues and international conferences, patents, half a dozen book chapters, and a research monograph. The research was recognized through four best paper awards (1 journal and 3 conferences), and the PI received additional prestigious awards over the course of the project. Those include the McKnight Presidential Endowed Chair at the University of Minnesota (since 2016); the IEEE Technical Field Fourier Award (2015); the IEEE-SPS "Norbert Wiener" Society Award (2019); EURASIP's "A. Papoulis" Society Award (2020); the IEEE ComSocEducation Award (2019); foreign membership of the AcademiaEuropaea (2020), and fellowships of the US National Academy of Inventors (2019); and the European Academy of Sciences (2020).
